description.narrative: Decrease diabetes distress and psychosocial distress among older men and women living with or at risk of developing diabetes

Our work will directly reach 6,000 vulnerable older men and women living with or at risk for developing diabetes, with indirect beneficiaries from their households numbering 30,000 (based on an average family size 6). The target population will be 50% Syrian refugees, and 50% drawn from vulnerable host communities, primarily Lebanese, but also Palestinians and Iraqis.

This is a co-funding activity in support of our wider programme on diabetes in Lebanon. This work seeks to enhance access to diabetes screening, treatment, referral and prevention care for older men & women with Type 2 diabetes, or at risk of developing it. Our work will directly reach 6,000 vulnerable older men and women living with or at risk for developing diabetes, with indirect beneficiaries from their households numbering 30,000 (based on an average family size 6). The target population will be 50% Syrian refugees, and 50% drawn from vulnerable host communities, primarily Lebanese, but also Palestinians and Iraqis.
To enhance access to diabetes screening, treatment, referral and prevention care for older men & women with T2D or at risk of developing it
To increase the awareness of older men and women living with or at risk of developing diabetes about diabetes risk factors and complications

mailing-address.narrative: Tavis House, 1-6 Tavistock Square, London WC1H 9NA
